Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Essential Functions of Secondary Metabolic Networks for Bacterial Competition

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
While secondary metabolites are organic compounds that are considered to be nonessential for survival, bacteria are known to produce these compounds for important specialized functions. Some secondary metabolites inhibit or destroy competitors. Others are signals to control transitions between cellular states, such as biofilm formation and swarming. Traditional studies of secondary metabolites involve purified molecules that are tested on isolated species. However, bacteria predominantly exist in complex multi-species communities, which select for robust competitive mechanisms. Therefore the question as to how networks of secondary metabolites function in the competition between species is not addressed by such traditional approaches. This NSF CAREER project focuses on examining mixed-species cultures that expands the range of detectable bioactive metabolites and their competitive functions. Based on preliminary data that indicate several secreted metabolites are exchanged between Bacillus subtilis and Streptomyces sp. Mg1, microbial genetics in combination with physiological and developmental analyses will be used to determine the role of the compounds in the competition between these two species for limited resources. Further, studies of metabolic activity will be integrated with innovative imaging mass spectrometry to assess the net impact of multiple active metabolites. Secreted enzymes that contribute to the competitive success of the species producing the secondary metabolites will also be identified. This project will provide a new view of secondary metabolic networks in bacterial competition.

Broader Impacts
The research goals of this project are interwoven with education and outreach programs to promote public awareness and understanding of natural sources of antibiotics, which are microbial secondary metabolites, and their metabolism. The education program will produce and disseminate basic knowledge of bacterial ecology, metabolism, and synthesis of secondary metabolites via coursework and laboratory studies that focus on microbial interactions and emphasize a changing perspective on bacteria from single pathogenic entities to communal organisms. The coursework also includes database development and web-based interfaces accessible to students and the public, and so is integrated with the outreach program, which will convey the same basic knowledge to wider audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on deciphering chemical mechanisms that bacteria use to compete between species. Bacteria are misunderstood organisms. While some are agents of disease, others are the producers of antibiotics that may be used to treat infections. The evolution of these bacterial traits arises from a long natural history of interactions between different species in the environment. Modern microbiology has revealed that bacteria are communal organisms and that communities depend on the outcomes of interactions between species. However, the mechanisms that bacteria use to interact, cooperatively or competitively, are poorly understood. This project developed and used a model system of two species, Bacillus and Streptomyces, to discover their respective chemical and genetic mechanisms for interaction. The bacteria used in this study are of great importance in the environment as soil bacteria and to humans as sources of antibiotics. Understanding their interaction mechanisms not only reveals how bacteria may operate in communities, but how their interactions may influence the evolution of antibiotics and antibiotic resistance.

The outcomes of this project have two important impacts: one is a deeper understanding of the complexity of competition between two species of bacteria and the other is an expanded understanding of bacteria and their contributions to humankind.

Intellectual Merit: Through a focus on two species, the project revealed that competition does not always have a simple, predictable outcome. Each species produces multiple antibiotic-like metabolites that provoke a response from competitors. Linearmycins were discovered to be membrane-targeting lytic agents produced by some Streptomyces species. The project revealed that Bacillus subtilis exposed to linearmycins could activate a resistance function that had two effects. The resistance function prevented cell lysis and initiated biofilm formation, providing two pathways of protection from the linearmycins. The project revealed that chloramphenicol, a classic antibiotic produced by Streptomyces venezuelae, is detected by B. subtilis at low concentrations. When B. subtilis encounters chloramphenicol, it mobilizes the population of its cells and escapes the effects of the antibiotic. This newly identified adaptive response to antibiotics is an indicator that bacteria may respond in unknown ways to antibiotics in the environment or in our bodies.

Broader Impacts: This project integrated research, education, and outreach throughout its duration. A course on the Origins and Actions of Antibiotics was developed and taught to students nationally and internationally. Undergraduates do not typically have access to courses on antibiotics. Given the importance of antibiotics to modern medicine and the problematic rise in antibiotic resistance, a broader understanding of these concepts in our society will positively impact the preservation of effective antibiotics. The project continuously sought new approaches to investigate bacterial interactions. One approach led to the development of a low-cost, easy to build system to record changes in gene expression in a population of bacteria. Integral to this work was a project by a Masters in Fine Arts student. This project produced artistic photographs and videos that were used to showcase the valuable intersection of arts and science as a means of communicating knowledge and inspiration from the natural world.
